projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Sir HARRY VANE'S LAST SIGH FOR The Committee of Safety, Breathed forth in Diſcourſes and Conferences with the Right Honorable, VICE-ADMIRAL LAWSON, On the Seventeenth of December 1659. aboard the GREAT JAMES.
LONDON: Printed in the Year of our Lord. 1659.

div.head: Sir HARRY VANE'S laſt Sigh for the Committee of Safety, &c.
div.p:
THe Committee of Safety, and the moſt Illuſtrious Council of Officers aſſembled at Wallingford Houſe, having received the ſad and doleful news of Lawſons Revolt from their depraved Deſigns, were now in a peck of Troubles: Hath he, quoth they, forſaken us in the midſt of our adverſities, and deſerted us in the moſt unfortunate Juncture of our Calamities? At this they ſighed, and looked demurely toward Heaven, yet not ſo, but that a man might perceive ſuch a kinde of malice mixt therewith, as threatned God himſelf for not giving a ſatisfactory anſwer to the demands of their late publick and private Faſts. From lamenting they fell to debating, and after they had turn'd over all the leaves of their Imaginations, they could finde but one Receipt to ſtop the bleeding Wound of their almoſt periſhing Intereſt: For to revive their dull and drooping ſpirits, up ſteps Sir Harry Vane, who opening his mouth, thus beſpake the Congregation of Warlike Saints, Quoth he, I did not think, dear Brethren, I profeſs I did not think our late Vice-Admiral would have left us in the Suds (God grant we may ſcape their ſcowring) I thought he had been a ſurer Card, I thought we might have plaid with him ſecurely, and that he would have prov'd a Trump, yea a conſtant Van Trump unto us, even to the winning of our Game, but it ſeems it proves otherwiſe, yet it may be that I
may reclaim him for all this; I am ſure he ows muc • unto me, for when he was but an infant, and knew nothing of miſchief, I ſuckled him with the ſweet milk of State Policy, I brought him into employment, and taught him to climb the ſhaouds of Preferment, and having nurſed him to full maturity, placed him where he is, But Ahitophel was miſtaken, and therefore may now go ſet his houſe in order. hoping that he would prove unto us the Inſtrument of our ſalvation; therefore I will go ſpeak with him, and put home his ingratitude to his heart, and if his heart be not over hardned, I may perchance cauſe him to relent. Oh, quoth Fleetwood, talk not of ingratitude, and then weeping more bitterly than St Peter, my ingratitude, ſaid he, hath undone me, for I pull'd out my Brother in Law by the ears, for which I could now tear my fleſh; what hopes have we to finde him other wiſe than ingrateful, that were ſo our ſelves? But Sir Harry commending the oylineſs of his tongue, and his Ulyſſes-like ſubtilty, prevail'd with them that he might make a tryal of them both, and was forth with commanded, without delay, to make the utmoſt proof of his skill in that their time of diſtreſs. Now that he might not go alone, there were added to him Major Saloway, in whom they imagin'd there was much Oratory, becauſe he once dealt in Raiſons, and Mr. Thankful Owen, a Prieſt of a late Edition, one who having miſt the great Harveſt wherein Marſhal, Nye, and Peters reap'd, is now come into play, thinking to pick up the gleanings of Ephraim, whoſe buſineſs doubtleſs was to urge Scripture, and with his Chriſten name to put the Vice-admiral in mind of Sir Harry's former kindneſſes; with theſe went along one Mr. Courtney, famous for nothing, but that he was a chip of the ſame block.
On the 17. inſtant they went aboard the James, where they found the Vice-Admiral not alone, but having his Aſſiſtants with him, Colonel Okey, and Mr. Scot, one able to encounter the ſubtilties of Sir Harry, well knowing every chink and cranny of his brain. Then retreating into the great Cabin, they fell to work.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Vice-Admiral, I am come.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: I ſee you are come, but to what purpoſe I know not; had your Lady come, I might have thought ſhe had longed to eat ſome of our Ship-Beef.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: I ſay Sir, I am come from the Committee of Safety.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: No, but you are not; for you are come from the Committee of Danger, or to ſpeak more properly, you are come from the Committee in Danger.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: They may thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: I know no reaſon I have given them to be ſo courteous: but I have heard that there is craft in courteſie, which I believe is the reaſon that you give me this viſit.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: 'Tis the good of the Commonwealth that draws me hither.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: Truly I cannot believe it; for you yet bear about you the badge of Kingſhip, and your Name ſtill wears a Title received from Monarchy.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: My wife will not let me leave it off, out of a reſolution ſhe has to dye a Lady.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p:
But to board your grand Deſign: What is your Errand hither? I know you have ſeen a great Ship before; there was never a one launch'd, but
you were invited aboard, when you were a Commiſſioner of the Navy. You got ſweetly by that, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: And ſo may you get too, if you'll be rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Sir, you have put your hand to the Plough, and it is a great ſin to draw it back.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: Sir, I am not to anſwer for that ſin, let it light on the head of your Major General Diſborow.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: But, Sir, will you not receive money? 'Tis the mark of a Saint not to refuſe it.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: For what ſhould I receive it? or who ſhould give it me?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Honeſtly ſpoke, Sir Harry. I, and my Faction will, ſo you engage to betray your Truſt.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: 'Tis fairly promiſed; but for ought I ſee, you have none, I will not ſay, for your ſelves; but none to pay your ſmall Army: and for us at Sea, you can hardly allow us Bisket. But would you then have me to betray my Truſt, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Yes, for the good of the Publick: and truly if you do not, I ſhall not take you for a Saint; for gold will tempt a Saint.

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.p: Truly, Sir Harry, though you have an Engliſh Noſe, yet you have got a Roman Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: But pray Sir Harry make good your Paradox.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p:
That I ſhall, and with eaſe. You ſeem to be unwilling to take money to betray your Truſt; now I ſhall make it out that you may: for, thoſe things we call ſins, are no ſins, if he that commits them do direct
his intention aright. As for example: Should you take money of us, out of a malicious deſign to betray your Truſt, Excellent doctrine. and be revenged upon thoſe that employed you, then it were a ſin: but your intention being directed to your own advantage and profit, which is a good to your ſelf, and a thing which a man may lawfully ſeek after, this makes it ceaſe to be a crime. Thus an Incumbent may without any mortal ſin, wiſh the death of him that hath a Penſion out of his Living: And a Son may wiſh the death of his Father, and rejoyce when it happens; provided, it proceed onely from a conſideration of the advantage which accrues to him thereby, and not out of any perſonal hatred.

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.p: Truly Sir Harry I have writ many a Sermon in the Abby, but never heard this doctrine before now.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: It may be ſo, Sir, but I have ſeen it practized before now, and could bring you the example of many profeſſors to prove it.

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.p: I have heard you ſpeak, Sir Harry, and the Vice-admiral may doe what he pleaſes; but if he would be perſwaded by me, I ſhould not adviſe him to run into hell head-long.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Surely, Mr. Scot, I never fear'd any ſuch place; and I thought you had been ſo much a States-man as not to have fear'd it neither.

sp.speaker: Salmon.
sp.p: Verily, I am perſwaded in my ſpirit, Mr. Lawſon, that you ought to obey the Preſent power, truly I have alwayes obeyed the Preſent power, and I hope ſhall as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p:
I thank the Lord I can be comformable to my Superiors, when they conform to my intereſt, and therefore Mr. Vice-admiral, truly I would have you be
conformable to them, ſince they ſeek to be conformable to you. Certainly if you will not own them, the Lord will own his own cauſe.

sp.speaker: Courtney.
sp.p: With a tobaco pipein • mouth For my part, I think out Diviſions do but give advantages to the common Enemy, and therefore I would have you make an end of theſe differences.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I ſee here you all ſpeak me fair for your own Intereſt: 'tis true, your Intelligencer General ſaid, that your Intereſt would not lie, but he is ſuch a lying fellow himſelf, that I can neither believe him, nor you neither for his ſake. But now I take of Intereſt, pray tell me what your Intereſt is.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Our Intereſt is the good of the Nation.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.p: So ſays Charls Stewart, but what reaſon have I to believe you more then him?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: 'Tis that we have fought for. No Kingſhip, and the Liberty of the Subject.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: What becomes then of the Priviledges of Parliament?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: My L. Lambert has taken them away, leſt they ſhould take away him: You know his ſon was to marry Lamberts daughter, but we doubt the Match is ſpoil'd, and truly my Intereſt is ſo woven with his, that I cannot ſafely forſake him.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: Why, then you are for a ſingle Perſon?

sp.speaker: Vane
sp.p: No! we will have Conſervators joyned with him.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: Conſervators! I underſtand not the word: and truly, Gentlemen, I am clearly againſt a Government of Hard Names.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: But the word may be explained; they are men elected to preſerve the peace of the Nation.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: By what power?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: By your Council of Officers, according to the Inſtrument of Government.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: What is become of that Inſtrument?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: We did light our Tobacco with it in the Council-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: And would you be governed by a thing which you have ſo contemptibly thrown away? Truly, Gentlemen, I ſee you would have ſomething, but know not what your ſelves: and therefore, as you may ſee in print, I do here again declare poſitively, for the laſt Parliament, whoſe ſubverſion you did, and ſtill do ſo laboriouſly intend.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: That's no Parliament, or, at moſt, but the Rump of a Parliament.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: The better able to ſit, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: But they will turn me out; and then people will cry, There goes the Parliament Fart.

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.p: 'Tis very probable: and I wiſh that they could ſo turn you out, that you might leave no ſtink behinde.

sp.speaker: Saloway.
sp.p: Truly, I wonder at you, Vice-Admiral, that you ſhould be for that which all the people hate, The Rump of a Parliament.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: Then it ſeems, good man of Plums, the people do not hate you at all.

sp.speaker: Saloway.
sp.p: Alas, We care not for their hatred: and would you but ſtick by us with your Navy, then we ſhould have an Army to quell them, and we might then with as much eaſe ride upon the backs of the people, as on the backs of our Horſes. Beſides, it is a ſign that you are Epiſcopal, it being the attribute of a Biſhop to love Rumps.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: I hope not ſo, Major; for I love Rumps and Kidneys too, and yet I am no Biſhop.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: Truly, Major, I finde neither of your Reaſons to be thorough-pac'd: for, as to the former, the Gentleman that ſpoke laſt, hath given you a ſufficient anſwer: and as to the latter, give me leave to tell you, 'tis an ill time to ride the people, for I perceive them to be in a very skittiſh poſture.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Really, Gentlemen, I think this difference might be eaſily reconciled: For I ſee the Vice-Admiral is for a Parliament; and if ſo, why may not another Parliament ſerve his turn as well as this? therefore, ſay I, let us have a new Parliament, and a free one, once more elected. For, to ſay truth, Vice Admiral, ſhould that Parliament ſit which you ſtand for, we are utterly loſt: And what harm have we done you, that you ſhould ſeek our confuſion?

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: What think you of a Parliament of women? Truly Vice-admiral, I am confident they would ſettle the Miniſtery, for I finde them very reſpective to me in particular.

sp.speaker: Vice-Admiral.
sp.p: Sir, you ſpeak gravely, but not at all wiſely.

sp.speaker: Salmon.
sp.p: Certainly we might bound and confine the Election to ſuch qualifications, that neither you nor we might receive any prejudice by it. For my part I am clearly againſt Swearers and Whoremongers.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: And I am for no Cavaliers.

sp.speaker: Courtney.
sp.p: Nor I for Adulterers.

sp.speaker: Saloway.
sp.p: I am for no Papiſts.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: I would have them all gifted men, and Praiſe-God Barebones.

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.p: You talk, Gentlemen, as if you were to chuſe a Parliament in the Kingdom of Chriſt: for theſe Exceptions are not to be made on Earth, unleſs you, Maſter Owen, can take ſinne out of the World. And as for Praiſe God Barebones, let us have no more of them for they deliver'd up our Liberties before into the hands of a ſingle Perſon. But, I pray Gentlemen, why do ye ſpeak againſt them whom you call the Rump? What power have you to hinder them? Doth not Sir Arthur increaſe? and the Vice-Admiral ſtand bravely to his Tackling for it? Then with what impudent faces can you make theſe Propoſals in the low ebbe of your condition? for my part, I think we are as wiſe as you, and as cunning as you, and as good men as you, and therefore why we may not govern as well as you, I know no reaſon?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Truly, Vice-Admiral, this Gentleman hath ſpoke well; but the Government is now in our hands, and ſhould there be another. Change, and that ſo ſuddenly, what would our Neighbors, but accuſe us for the moſt light and inconſtant Nation of the whole World.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: In anſwer to this, I ſhall tell ye, that when you put them out, it was force, but if they put you out, you ought in Chriſti • n piety to ſuffer it: for you muſt do as you would be done unto. Now ſince you put the Change upon them, you muſt not take it ill that they put the Change upon you.

sp.speaker: Saloway.
sp.p: But this is not the way to ſettle the Nation.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p:
And when do you think Lambert will ſettle it? Surely, he loves himſelf too well, to ſettle
the Nation before he ſettle himſelf; and when he will do that, who can tell, ſince he muſt ask Monck leave before he can do it. Or if he ſhould ſettle it, who will ſecure us that Sir Harry Vane will not trouble it again? I am ſure none of his friends in New-England, for they knew him too well, and were glad they were rid of him.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Had I known you would have been at this lock, I would ſoon have ſpoiled your troubling of us now.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: But now 'tis paſt your skill and cunning, good Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: The worſe is my luck, and the better yours, Mr. Vice-Admiral. But give me leave, Sir, to tell you, You are not a little ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: Accuſe not me, Sir Harry, are not you ſo, and does not all the world know that your Father was ſo before you?

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Is it then Reſolved upon the Queſtion, Mr. Vice-Admiral?

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: 'Tis without Queſtion, Sir Harry, and that ſo ſtedfaſtly, that I am not to be moved by the moſt refined of your language.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p:
Well! I have now been a Stateſman this twenty years: And I have been the Anak of many Factions, but I was never ſo deſerted, as now, before: and by a friend Vice-Admiral? Et tu quo
que Brute.

sp.speaker: Scot.
sp.p: 'Twas time, Sir Harry, to call for aſſiſtance from the Sea, when you, like a State-Phaeton, had put the Nation into ſuch a flame.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p:
Come, come, Mr. Scot, you know what belongs to Government, and you know what a ſweet thing
it is to be in Authority, and how ſowre a thing it is to leave it: and therefore you cannot blame me for endevouring by all ways to ſecure my ſelf and intereſt.

sp.speaker: Salmon.
sp.p: Really, Sir, we have had experience of your diligence, and give you our hearty thanks; and ſhall juſtifie the ſame to the Commiſſioners, who, no doubt, will not be backward in rewarding your good ſervice.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Tom Telltroth. But were not I more concerned than you or they either, ye might go drive Hogs all of ye, for me.

sp.speaker: Vice-admiral.
sp.p: Come, this high-ſoaring ſpirit of yours muſt ſtoop. You that walk upon the ſtilts of Ambition, will fall at one time or other: and truly, I think, you had as good fall now as hereafter.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: But Mr. Scot, I have done no harm, I hope you will let me keep my ſmall imployment ſtill; though if you will not, I thank my God, I have made ſo good uſe of my time, that I can live without it.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Scot, I came onely to give the Vice-Admiral a viſit; therefore, I truſt in the Lord, you will not put me out of my Living: Truly, I will preach for you too, when you are in authority.

sp.speaker: Saloway.
sp.p: I care not a pin for any of ye all, ſo you will let me have talk enough for my life.

sp.speaker: Vane.
sp.p: I ſcorn to beg; yet I believe I ſhall finde a trick to keep my Head upon my ſhoulders for all this.

sp.speaker: Okey.
sp.p: If you do, Sir Harry, 'tis more than three parts of four in the Nation deſire to ſee.

div.p: The Debate being thus broke off, they returned to Wallingford-Houſe; The fruitleſneſs of the Journey was arrived at their ears before; ſo that when they ſaw Sir Harry, they look'd all as melancholly as Cars. Quoth he. I can do no good. Then Fleetwood turning his face to the wall, lifted up his voice, and wept. Then one ſtood up, and ſaid, Let us ſeek the Lord by faſting and prayer. But it was rejected, in regard that Fleetwood looked ſo thin, that if he ſhould faſt one day more, his Soul and Body could not hold together. Whereupon they fell to debate their Agreement, which is now in print: But whether they will get ſuch terms as they require, a little time will make known. However, the people take the Parliament for wiſe men, and therefore they expect that they ſhould ſo deal with this Hydra, as not to let one head thereof ſpring up any more, to violate their Priviledges, or the Nations Rights.
